OriginalSource.Creator: Terese Winslow
OriginalSource.Comment: Note from Multimedia team: cancer cells in duct do not need to be labeled
Made the nipple rash more prominent and brighter red, faded the lobes/ducts a bit and removed the DCIS inset and abnormal cells label from the cross-sectional view of the breast
Refinements made to the blow-out duct and to the leader lines for the “Ducts” and “Abnormal cells” labels.
Removed the drop of liquid coming from the nipple area in the inset

Faded the lobules, ducts, and lymph nodes in the front view of the breast; combined the side view of the breast and the inset into one; made the cells in the inset look more like DCIS (flatter as in our DCIS image) and labeled them “Abnormal cells; kept the abnormal cells within the duct; and changed the label “Ductal carcinoma” to “Ductal carcinoma in situ”

ContentDescriptions.ContentDescription: Paget disease of the breast; drawing shows a front view of the breast with redness and crusting of the nipple and areola (the darker circle of skin around the nipple). Also shown is a cross section of the breast with cancer cells in the breast ducts.

Captions.MediaCaption: Paget disease of the breast is a rare type of cancer involving the nipple and usually the areola (the darker circle of skin around the nipple). It can look similar to skin conditions such as eczema and dermatitis. Symptoms usually include redness in the nipple and/or areola and itchy, crusty, flaking, or thickened skin on or around the nipple. People with Paget disease may also have a tumor in the same breast.

ProcessingStatus.ProcessingStatusValue: Approved by expert reviewer with changes
